awd_titl_txt: Build and Broaden: Growing Capacity in Research Examining Entrepreneurship
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

The goals of this project are to examine entrepreneurship among minority communities and identify how success varies for individuals who experience discrimination. The proposed research utilizes interviews and focus groups to better understand the factors that shape the success or failure of entrepreneurial ventures among entrepreneurs of color and the ways in which discrimination shapes the pursuit of independent business ventures. This study will also evaluate how individuals understand their entrepreneurship as part of their larger social environment and as a strategy for change. Findings from this project will be useful to policymakers as well as to organizations seeking to support entrepreneurship within marginalized communities. This project will create opportunities for collaboration within minority-serving institutions, provide opportunities for minority students and community members to build research capacity through training and experience, and promote examples of the resilience of minority entrepreneurs.

The researchers will conduct interviews and focus groups with key informants to construct case studies of minority entrepreneurs and their businesses. Qualitative data will be collected from multiple racial-ethnic communities on the practices and experiences of minority entrepreneurs, and on the extent to which social, legal and racial forms of discrimination shape the process and success of their entrepreneurial ventures. Results will contribute to the theoretical understandings of how individual and environmental factors affect the development of entrepreneurial ventures and shed light on the relationship between entrepreneurship and social mobility.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

pi.pi_full_name: Maria Paola Di Sessa De Luca Ometto

inst.inst_name: California State University San Marcos Corporation
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY SAN MARCOS CORP

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: California State University San Marcos Corporation

por.por_cntn:
Our projects goal was to understand how individual and environmental factors facilitate the development of entrepreneurial ventures, and the relationship between entrepreneurship and social exclusion.   We focused our research on individuals from the following marginalized groups: Black, Latino, Asian, undocumented, and previously incarcerated in a large metropolitan area in the United States. Over the course of three years we successfully collected a detailed data set that will provide opportunities for analysis and theory development about these issues for years to come: we ultimately conducted and recorded 107 individual interviews and 6 focus groups, including 27 focus group members. We also conducted ethnographic observation at over 40 events.  We have been analyzing our data using sociological and entrepreneurial literatures to inform an empirical exploration of the ways marginalized groups cohere and mobilize in the face of exclusion to develop new business ventures. Overall, our results showed that those entrepreneurs from marginalized race-ethnic identities who narrate persistence and growth were constantly juggling their identities and had the ability to invisibilize, camouflage, and leverage their race-ethnicity in adaptive response to the context depending on how discriminatory or open the context is to their identities. We identified the characteristics that allow entrepreneurs to adapt to a dynamic and persistent environment of adversity: early experiences of socialization in White/diverse environments, internal sources of confidence, and the ability to brush off discrimination. Furthermore, our findings showed that most of the entrepreneurs we interviewed did not start their businesses because they had been totally excluded from the labor market, but they did feel a lack of esteem for their knowledge and expertise, limited possibilities for professional progress, and a desire to shed the limitations imposed upon them by discriminatory social and professional environments. For most of the entrepreneurs we interviewed, the income made through their business was not their sole source of income, often complementing formal employment; and many described incurring debt or just breaking even with their businesses. They described how entrepreneurship became a space for personal expression by creating new rules, structures and relationships that allowed them to create an enterprise according to their views and ideals. Our participants work to create inclusive and safe spaces for other marginalized people with their businesses.

We have disseminated our results by presenting at national and international academic conferences from distinguished associations: Academy of Management, American Sociological Association, Society for the Advancement of Socio-Economics, and European Group for Organization Studies. We integrated our research into both classroom and university administrative realms. We have also finalized two manuscripts to send for journal publication.

Our project created many opportunities for collaboration between Department of Management in the College of Business Administration and the Department of Human Development, as well as provided opportunities for minority students on our campus to build research capacity through training and experience. Over the course of three years we involved 23 student assistants, many who continued working with us until they graduated. Our research assistants were trained in project planning, data collection techniques- including interview, focus group, and ethnographic methods- as well as in qualitative data analysis. They proceeded to present at professional conferences with data from our work, and 5 of them went on to pursue graduate studies with our support. All of our students gained skills as well as professional experience that will serve them in their professional development and assist their ability to attain future employment.

Our project has also provided benefits for the communities in which we are embedded. We held 5 community events in which community members received training and mentorship, as well as offered their feedback on our findings. We hosted 2 winter markets in which we featured BIPOC vendors, and over 400 community members had contact with their businesses. We launched a website that highlights businesses of color and their founders, as well as resources and supports available in the region for entrepreneurs. This website will bring community attention and support to existing businesses while also providing models for young people of color who are interested in entrepreneurship. Our project has worked to lift up stories of those who typically face legal exclusion and social discrimination to recognize their resilience and power.  

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 01/29/2025
Modified by: Carly Offidani-Bertrand
